name: Barbier, François
title: (id003008) NA; (id007801) NA
notes: (id003008) NA ;(id007801) Printer-bookseller at Poitiers from c.1776-c.1818. Almanach de la Librarie for 1781 lists him as business partner of Jean-Felix Faulcon, his father-in-law, whom he succeeded as printer in 1783. A permission given to a François Barbier supposedly of Saumur was clearly intended for the Poitiers printer, and so the data has been corrected in the actual place of publication.

name: Barbou, Joseph-Gérard
title: (id003888) NA; (id007955) NA
notes: (id003888) NA ;(id007955) Permission simple notes: Only one Barbou is listed in the Almanach de la Librairie, 1781, as a printer specialising in Livres classiques. This matches with data in Permission simple register, which describes Barbou as a 'printer' and recipient for a permission for an edition of Cicero's letters. In business 1752 to 1789 according to Mellot et al.

name: Bastien, Jean-François
title: (id001692) NA; (id003278) NA
notes: (id001692) Stock Sales Notes: Active 1771-c.1822. Also in FBTEE-1 database. Details here after Mellot et al. Confiscations notes: Identity confirmed by imprint in confiscated books 'Eloge de Voltaire' and worldcat match for confiscation record 1035. Permission simple notes: Source data describes Bastien as a libraire and Mellot et al., and Almanach de la Librairie (1781) identify only one person of this name active in Paris at this time: Jean-Francois Bastien (1747-1824, traded 1771-c.1822). ;(id003278) NA

name: Batilliot
title: (id001693) NA; (id008293) M.
notes: (id001693) NB MS1106 is damaged here an at least two more letters in CLG1 or CLG2 should be assumed. ;(id008293) It has been assumed that the many references to Bastilliot, Batilliot and Batillot in the confiscation register, all dating from period 1778-1784, refer to the same person. However, no external references to booksellers of this name prior to 1790 are found in CERL. Thereafter examples in Paris and Cap François. Unusually, Batilliot never signed the register himself, and his works were collected by several different agents, thought the names A. Huin, Lavocat, and Petit recur.

name: Bruyset
title: (id001187) NA; (id001188) NA; (id001190) NA; (id007814) NA
notes: (id001187) NA ;(id001188) NA ;(id001190) Succeeded Pierre Bruyset Ponthus. Permission simple notes: Recorded as a bookselling business in the Almanach de la Librairie for 1781, although J.-M. Bruysset the father is also listed as a Printer in the same source. Presumably this is because the son gained permission to serve as a bookseller in 1768 but was only received as a printer in 1783. Early permission simples attributed to J.-M. Bruysset probably therefore refer only to the father. The father-son partnership apparently lasted from 1774 to c. 1791 according to Mellot et al. The older Jean-Marie Bruysset traded from c. 1744 to c.1791 and died in 1793; the younger Jean-Marie Bruysset, the eldest of his sons, was condemned to death in the Terror for printing 'billets obsidionaux' during the siege of Lyon, but his brother Pierre-Marie died in his place (25-12-1793) and he lived on until 1817. ;(id007814) Bruyset imprimeur-libraire could at this date apply to Jean-Marie Bruyset, pere, (1719-1793); his son Jean-Marie Bruysset (1744-1817), who became a printer in 1784, or their business partnership. Due to these ambiguities, this reference has been treated as a separate client.

Identified through Mellot et al. Present as adjoint at Brunet stock sale in Dec. 1787. Not to be confused with his son F.-P.-V. Cailleau, fils, (active from 1788). Confiscations notes: Signature matches other Cailleau signatures, with addition of initial, further confirming identification. ;(id003253) NA

name: Couret de Villeneuve, Louis-Pierre
title: (id004326) NA; (id007832) Mr.
notes: (id004326) NA ;(id007832) At date of this entry, Louis-Pierre was only Couret de Villeneuve in the trade according to CERL. Permission simple notes: Listed as printer-bookseller, Couret de Villeneuve, fils, in the Almanach de la Librarie for 1781; Mellot et al. clarfiy that he traded at Orleans from 1771 to 1794, when he went into liquidation (though also established at Paris 1791-8 and in Orleans again 1797) and gained his printer's status in 1776. Earliest two permissions to Couret de Villeneuve, dating from 1797, could possibly belong to his father, Martin Couret de Villeneuve (died 21 October 1780), who was also a printer-bookseller at Orleans. Louis-Pierre was also successor to his father and brother in law to the media baron Charles-Joseph Panckoucke.

name: Lallemant, Richard-Gontran
title: (id004173) NA; (id007877) M.
notes: (id004173) NA ;(id007877) Rouen bookdealer; books on this confiscation came from Rouen. Permission simple notes: Richard-Gontran Lallemant [or Lallemand / l'Allemand] was named as a printer-bookseller in the 1781 Almanach de la Librairie and according to Mellot et al. was in business 1754 to c. 1790. Son of Nicolas Lallement, who resigned in his favour in 1754, and received printer in place of another printer in the same year. Ennobled by letters patent (1775) when gained a hereditary privilege over printing in Rouen - hence his imprint 'l'Imprimerie privile?gie?e' and variants. Died 1807.

Due to context, has been assumed to be a Libraire. ;(id008736) possibly the Parisian bookseller Le Comte listed as client cp0184.

name: Morin
title: (id000834) NA; (id001830) Mme; (id008164) NA; (id009783) NA
notes: (id000834) NA ;(id001830) NA ;(id008164) Permission simple notes: Described as printer specialising in devotional works and based in rue Saint-Jacques in 1781 Almanach de la Librairie, but as Libraire in the Permission Simple registers. This is still probably the same Morin, however, as in 1783 Benoît Morin went bankrupt and had to cede his printshop. Continued in trade til 1802. Seems to be only Morin trading in Paris at time granted permission simple. Dates trading in Paris Nov. 1772 to 1717 (as printer-bookseller Nov 1772-1783; as bookseller thereafter). ;(id009783) Customs register signatory might be Benoi?t Morin, who suffered a couple of confiscations around this time, but lack of signature or other confirmatory evidence mean this is only conjecture.

name: Paulet, Jean-Jacques
title: (id001838) NA; (id010005) NA
notes: (id001838) NA ;(id010005) Censor for medicine. ID after 'Commentaires de la Faculté de médecine de Paris , 1777 à 1786 : publiés sous les auspices du Conseil de l'Université / Professeur A. Pinard ... H. Varnier ... H. Hartmann ... F. Widal ... G. Steinheil', p. 575, where he is identified as censor ( https://archive.org/stream/b28039221_0001/b28039221_0001_djvu.txt). Paulet was a member of the Faculties of Medicine of the Universities of Montpellier and Paris. His address is given in Almanac royal, 1786 as rue des Poitevins.

name: Racine, Jean
title: (id002027) NA; (id005530) NA
notes: (id002027) Additional document - 1 printed 'circulaire' 01/11/1783.  Succeeded Machuel, see 'circulaire' 25/09/1783. Confiscations notes: Racine only listed as a libraire in other FBTEE datasets, but no other Racine listed in CERL, which lists him as Imprimeur-libraire. Permission simple notes: Listed in the Almanach de la Librarie for 1781 merely as a bookseller named Racine. Mellot et al say his presence in Rouen is attested from April 1781 and that he was an associate, then from Sept / October 1783 successor, to the bookseller Pierre Machuel, trading from the latter's address in rue de la Ganterie. Racine remained in business til around 1805, though in 1803 sold part of fonds. Died 1814 ;(id005530) NA

name: Thiriot
title: (id001890) NA; (id009006) M.
notes: (id001890) NA ;(id009006) According to the online 'Le Gazetier Universel: ressources numeriques sur la presse ancienne' at http://gazetier-universel.gazettes18e.fr/periodique/journal-litteraire-de-nancy-1782-1787, Thiriot published 2 vols of the 'Journal Litteraire de de Nancy' (IX-X) in Paris in 1782-3. Earlier and later vols were produced in Nancy by Haener or Lamort. nothing further on Thiriot has been found in the Almanach de la Librarie (1781), CERL or Worldcat. However his address for subscriptions was 'à Paris , chez M. Thiriot , rue de la Vieille-Bouderie', maison du parfumier.
